requirements: The core contributions of the paper have been reproduced.

sub_tasks.requirements: The environments used for the experiments outlined in section 4.1 and Appendix C.2 have been setup
The 7 non-sparse environments have been setup
The (MuJoCo) Hopper-v3 environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
Any version of the (MuJoCo) Hopper environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The (MuJoCo) Hopper environment is version "Hopper-v3" (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The (MuJoCo) Walker2d-v3 environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
Any version of the (MuJoCo) Walker2d environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The (MuJoCo) Walker2d environment is version "Walker2d-v3" (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
In the (MuJoCo) Walker2d environment, the observations are normalized when training DRL agents (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The (MuJoCo) Reacher-v2 environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
Any version of the (MuJoCo) Reacher environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The (MuJoCo) Reacher environment is version "Reacher-v2" (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The (MuJoCo) HalfCheetah-v3 environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
Any version of the (MuJoCo) HalfCheetah environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The (MuJoCo) HalfCheetah environment is version "HalfCheetah-v3" (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
In the (MuJoCo) HalfCheetah environment, the observations are normalized when training DRL agents (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The Selfish Mining environment has been correctly set up and can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The Network Defense environment has been correctly set up and and can be used to run experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
Any version of the network defense environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The network defence environment is version "Cage Challenge 2" (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The Autonomous Driving environment has been correctly set up and can be used to run experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
Any version of the autonomous driving environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The autonomous driving environment is the 'Macro-v1' environment powered by the MetaDrive simulator (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).
The 2 sparse environments from the main body have been setup
The Sparse MuJoCo Hopper environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments.
Any version of the (MuJoCo) Sparse Hopper environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments.
The (MuJoCo) Sparse Hopper environment is version "Hopper-v3"
The Sparse MuJoCo HalfCheetah environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments.
Any version of the (MuJoCo) Sparse HalfCheetah environment has been correctly set up and can be initialized can be used to run the experiments.
The (MuJoCo) Sparse HalfCheetah environment is version "HalfCheetah-v3"
In the (MuJoCo) Sparse HalfCheetah environment, the observations are normalized when training DRL agents (further information about this environment in Appendix C.2).

For each environment, a policy network agent compatible with PPO has been setup and pretrained. The policy networks may or may not have variants to ensure compatibility with each of the correctly setup environments
A policy network agent compatible with PPO has been setup and pretrained For the MuJoCo environments
For the MuJoCo environments, the policy network agents has been implemented
For the MuJoCo environments, code for pretraining the policy network agent on each environment has been setup
For each of the MuJoCo environments, a policy network agent has been pretrained, resulting in a pretrained policy network for each MuJoCo environment
A policy network agent compatible with PPO has been setup and pretrained for the selfish mining environment

For the selfish mining environment, the policy network agents has been implemented.  The network architecture of the PPO agent is a 4-layer Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) with a hidden size of 128, 128, 128, and 128 in each layer
For the selfish mining environment, code for pretraining the policy network agent has been setup
For the selfish mining environment, the policy network agent has been pretrained, resulting in a pretrained policy network
A policy network agent compatible with PPO has been setup and pretrained for the network defence environment
For the network defence environment, the policy network agents has been implemented
For the network defence environment, code for pretraining the policy network agent has been setup
For the network defence environment, the policy network agent has been pretrained, resulting in a pretrained policy network
A policy network agent compatible with PPO has been setup and pretrained for the autonomous driving environment
For the autonomous driving environment, the policy network agents has been implemented
For the autonomous driving environment, code for pretraining the policy network agent has been setup
For the autonomous driving environment, the policy network agent has been pretrained, resulting in a pretrained policy network
For each environment, the explanation methods used for the experiments are implemented as outlined in 3.3 and 4.1
For the MuJoCo environments, the explanation methods used for the experiments are implemented as outlined in 3.3 and 4.1
For the MuJoCo environments, the original StateMask explanation method (from Cheng et al., 2023, not the proposed "Ours") and its training setup have been implemented as outlined in 3.3
For the MuJoCo environments, the explanation method implementation relies on a mask network that outputs "0" for critical steps and "1" otherwise
For the MuJoCo environments, the mask network objective $J(\theta)$ has been implemented to match what is outlined in section 3.3, namely $J(\theta)=\min |\eta(\pi)-\eta(\bar{\pi})|$
For the MuJoCo environments, the optimization of the mask network objective of using prime-dual methods has been implemented.
For the MuJoCo environments, the original StateMask Explanation method can be selected as the explanation method during retraining
For the MuJoCo environments, the original StateMask Explanation method can be selected for generating rollouts (without training)
For the MuJoCo environments, the optimized StateMask explanation method (aka "OURS") and its training setup have been implemented as outlined in 3.3 and Algorithm 1
For the MuJoCo environments, the mask network objective has been transformed
For the MuJoCo environments, the objective being optimized is $J(\theta)=\max \eta(\bar{\pi})$, as outlined in section 3.3.
For the MuJoCo environments, the reward function is implemented such that an additional reward is given when the mask net outputs "1", as outlined in section 3.3.

For the MuJoCo environments, the additional reward given when the mask net outputs "1" is governed by a mutable hyperparameter, i.e., a hyperparameter whose value can be changed (without having to edit the code directly), corresponding to $\alpha$ in the paper. Alternative hyperparameter names are allowed, as long as the functionality remains the same.
For the MuJoCo environments, the optimization of the mask network objective now uses PPO rather than the prime-dual method
For the MuJoCo environments, The StateMask ("Ours") Explanation method can be selected as the explanation method during retraining
For the MuJoCo environments, The StateMask ("Ours") Explanation method can be selected for generating rollouts (without training)
For the MuJoCo environments, the "Random" Explanation method implementation as outlined in 4.1.
For the MuJoCo environments, the "Random" Explanation method has been implemented as outlined in 4.1, wherein critical steps are identified by randomly selecting previously visited states.
For the MuJoCo environments, the "Random" Explanation method can be selected as the explanation method during retraining
For the MuJoCo environments, the "Random" Explanation method can be selected for generating rollouts (without training)
For the selfish mining environment, the explanation methods used for the experiments are implemented as outlined in 3.3 and 4.1

The results of Experiment I have been reproduced, as outlined in Sections 4.2 and 4.3
For each environment, the explanation fidelity score metric has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and 4.2

For the MuJoCo environments, the explanation fidelity score metric has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and 4.2: by forcing a given pretrained policy network agent to take random actions starting from each identified critical time step and measuring the average and maximum reward change.

For the selfish mining environment, the explanation fidelity score metric has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and 4.2: by forcing a given pretrained policy network agent to take random actions starting from each identified critical time step and measuring the average and maximum reward change.

For the network defence environment, the explanation fidelity score metric has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and 4.2: by forcing a given pretrained policy network agent to take random actions starting from each identified critical time step and measuring the average and maximum reward change.

For the autonomous driving environment, the explanation fidelity score metric has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and 4.2: by forcing a given pretrained policy network agent to take random actions starting from each identified critical time step and measuring the average and maximum reward change.
For each environment, Experiment I has correctly been run as outlined in section 4.2 the "StateMask" and "Ours" explanation methods
For the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, Experiment I has correctly been run as outlined in section 4.2 for each of "StateMask" and "Ours" explanation methods
For the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, Experiment I has correctly been run as outlined in section 4.2 for the "StateMask" explanation method
For each of the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, the "StateMask" explanation method has been trained
For each of the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, the "StateMask" explanation method has been used to identify the top K most critical time steps. This has been repeated for K = 10%, 20%, 30% and 40%
For each of the the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, for the "StateMask" explanation method, the fidelity score metric has been measured for each K across 500 trajectories

For each of the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, the methodology explained in Experiment I using "StateMask" (training "StateMask", identifying the top K most critical time steps, and measuring the fidelity score) has been repeated for a total of 3 different random seeds
For the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, for the "StateMask" explanation method, code for measuring training time throughout training as outlined in Appendix C.3 and Table 4 has been implemented.
For the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, for the "StateMask" explanation method, training time has been measured throughout as outlined in Section 4.2
For the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, Experiment I has correctly been run as outlined in section 4.2 for the "Ours" explanation method
For each of the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, the "Ours" explanation method has been trained
For each of the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, the "Ours" explanation method has been used to identify the top K most critical time steps. This has been repeated for K = 10%, 20%, 30% and 40%
For each of the the non-sparse MuJoCo environments, for the "Ours" explanation method, the fidelity score metric has been measured for each K across 500 trajectories

The results pertaining to fidelity scores described in section 4.3 have been reproduced
Results have been reported in a format comparable to Figure 5 of the paper.
Results are reported for each of the correctly setup non-sparse environments.
For each environment, the fidelity scores are reported as the mean and standard deviation acrosss 3 seeds
The fidelity scores reported include all Top-K values of K = 10%, 20%, 30% and 40%
The fidelity scores reported include the Random baseline, StateMask and the paper's contributed Optimised StateMask (OURS)

For the section 4.3 results, the fidelity scores of StateMask and the Optimised StateMask proposed by the paper ("OURS") are generally comparable across the correctly setup non-sparse environments and K's
The results pertaining to training efficiency described in section 4.3 have been reproduced
Results have been reported in a format comparable to Table 4 of the paper

The training time (in seconds) is reported for StateMask explanation and the papers proposed optimised StateMask explanation ("Ours") for each of the correctly setup non-sparse environments considered, in a format comparable to Table 4 of the paper.
For each environment, the training time is reported for the same fixed number of training samples for both StateMask and "Ours"

For the results pertaining to training efficiency described in section 4.3, the results show that in general (i.e. across all environments) there is a noticeable drop in training time when using the paper's proposed optimised StateMask explanation method rather than the original StateMask explanation implementation.
For each environment, the refining methods used in the paper experiments (Section 4) have been implemented
For the MuJoCo environments, the refining methods used in the paper experiments (Section 4) have been implemented

For the MuJoCo environments, StateMask fine-tuning, aka "StateMask-R" has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and Cheng et al., 2023, i.e. resetting to the identified critical states and continuing training from there.
For the MuJoCo environments, the paper's contributed "Ours" Refining Method has been implemented as outlined in section 3.3.

For the MuJoCo environments, code for constructing a mixed initial state distribution by combining default initial states and critical states identified by the "Ours" explanation method has been implemented as described in Section 3.3.
For the MuJoCo environments, Random Network Distillation (RND) for exploration has been implemented as outlined in Section 3.3.
For the MuJoCo environments, the refining method has been implemented as outlined in Algorithm 2, integrating the mixed initial state distribution and RND.
For the MuJoCo environments, the refining method has been implemented such that it supports configuration via the hyperparameters outlined in section 3.3

For the MuJoCo environments, the refining method has been implemented to support the hyperparameter $\lambda$ to govern the trade-off between task reward and exploration bonus, as outlined in section 3.3. The $\lambda$ hyperparameter must be mutable i.e., a hyperparameter whose value can be changed (without having to edit the code directly). Alternative hyperparameter names are allowed, as long as the functionality remains the same.

For the MuJoCo environments, the refining method has been implemented to support the hyperparameter $p$, the probability threshold defining the mixed initial state distribution, as evidenced in Algorithm 2.  The $p$ hyperparameter must be mutable i.e., a hyperparameter whose value can be changed (without having to edit the code directly). Alternative hyperparameter names are allowed, as long as the functionality remains the same.
For the MuJoCo environments, the "PPO fine-tuning" refinement method has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1, i.e. lowering the learning rate and continuing training with the PPO algorithm.

For the MuJoCo environments, the Jump-Start Reinforcement Learning ("JSRL") refinement method has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and Uchendu et al. (2023), i.e. through initializing the exploration policy $\pi_{e}$ to be equal to the guided policy $\pi_{g}$.
For the selfish mining environment, the refining methods used in the paper experiments (Section 4) have been implemented

For the selfish mining environment, StateMask fine-tuning, aka "StateMask-R" has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and Cheng et al., 2023, i.e. resetting to the identified critical states and continuing training from there.
For the selfish mining environment, the paper's contributed "Ours" Refining Method has been implemented as outlined in section 3.3.

For the selfish mining environment, code for constructing a mixed initial state distribution by combining default initial states and critical states identified by the "Ours" explanation method has been implemented as described in Section 3.3.
For the selfish mining environment, Random Network Distillation (RND) for exploration has been implemented as outlined in Section 3.3.
For the selfish mining environment, the refining method has been implemented as outlined in Algorithm 2, integrating the mixed initial state distribution and RND.
For the selfish mining environment, the refining method has been implemented such that it supports configuration via the hyperparameters outlined in section 3.3

For the selfish mining environment, the refining method has been implemented to support the hyperparameter $\lambda$ to govern the trade-off between task reward and exploration bonus, as outlined in section 3.3.  The $\lambda$ hyperparameter must be mutable i.e., a hyperparameter whose value can be changed (without having to edit the code directly). Alternative hyperparameter names are allowed, as long as the functionality remains the same.

For the selfish mining environment, the refining method has been implemented to support the hyperparameter $p$, the probability threshold defining the mixed initial state distribution, as evidenced in Algorithm 2.  The $p$ hyperparameter must be mutable i.e., a hyperparameter whose value can be changed (without having to edit the code directly). Alternative hyperparameter names are allowed, as long as the functionality remains the same.

For the selfish mining environment, the "PPO fine-tuning" refinement method has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1, i.e. lowering the learning rate and continuing training with the PPO algorithm.

For the selfish mining environment, the Jump-Start Reinforcement Learning ("JSRL") refinement method has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and Uchendu et al. (2023), i.e. through initializing the exploration policy $\pi_{e}$ to be equal to the guided policy $\pi_{g}$.

For the network defence environment, the refining method has been implemented as outlined in Algorithm 2, integrating the mixed initial state distribution and RND.
For the network defence environment, the refining method has been implemented such that it supports configuration via the hyperparameters outlined in section 3.3

For the network defence environment, the refining method has been implemented to support the hyperparameter $\lambda$ to govern the trade-off between task reward and exploration bonus, as outlined in section 3.3.  The $\lambda$ hyperparameter must be mutable i.e., a hyperparameter whose value can be changed (without having to edit the code directly). Alternative hyperparameter names are allowed, as long as the functionality remains the same.

For the network defence environment, the refining method has been implemented to support the hyperparameter $p$, the probability threshold defining the mixed initial state distribution, as evidenced in Algorithm 2.  The $p$ hyperparameter must be mutable i.e., a hyperparameter whose value can be changed (without having to edit the code directly). Alternative hyperparameter names are allowed, as long as the functionality remains the same.

For the network defence environment, the "PPO fine-tuning" refinement method has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1, i.e. lowering the learning rate and continuing training with the PPO algorithm.

For the network defence environment, the Jump-Start Reinforcement Learning ("JSRL") refinement method has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and Uchendu et al. (2023), i.e. through initializing the exploration policy $\pi_{e}$ to be equal to the guided policy $\pi_{g}$.
For the autonomous driving environment, the refining methods used in the paper experiments (Section 4) have been implemented

For the autonomous driving environment, StateMask fine-tuning, aka "StateMask-R" has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and Cheng et al., 2023, i.e. resetting to the identified critical states and continuing training from there.
For the autonomous driving environment, the paper's contributed "Ours" Refining Method has been implemented as outlined in section 3.3.

For the autonomous driving environment, code for constructing a mixed initial state distribution by combining default initial states and critical states identified by the "Ours" explanation method has been implemented as described in Section 3.3.
For the autonomous driving environment, Random Network Distillation (RND) for exploration has been implemented as outlined in Section 3.3.
For the autonomous driving environment, the refining method has been implemented as outlined in Algorithm 2, integrating the mixed initial state distribution and RND.
For the autonomous driving environment, the refining method has been implemented such that it supports configuration via the hyperparameters outlined in section 3.3

For the autonomous driving environment, the refining method has been implemented to support the hyperparameter $\lambda$ to govern the trade-off between task reward and exploration bonus, as outlined in section 3.3.  The $\lambda$ hyperparameter must be mutable i.e., a hyperparameter whose value can be changed (without having to edit the code directly). Alternative hyperparameter names are allowed, as long as the functionality remains the same.

For the autonomous driving environment, the refining method has been implemented to support the hyperparameter $p$, the probability threshold defining the mixed initial state distribution, as evidenced in Algorithm 2.  The $p$ hyperparameter must be mutable i.e., a hyperparameter whose value can be changed (without having to edit the code directly). Alternative hyperparameter names are allowed, as long as the functionality remains the same.

For the autonomous driving environment, the "PPO fine-tuning" refinement method has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1, i.e. lowering the learning rate and continuing training with the PPO algorithm.

For the autonomous driving environment, the Jump-Start Reinforcement Learning ("JSRL") refinement method has been implemented as outlined in section 4.1 and Uchendu et al. (2023), i.e. through initializing the exploration policy $\pi_{e}$ to be equal to the guided policy $\pi_{g}$.

Code for pretraining a Soft Actor Critic (SAC) network agent on the dense MuJoCo Hopper environment has been implemented
Code for measuring reward throughout pretraining and refinement has been implemented
A pretrained agent trained with Soft Actor Critic (SAC) for 1M steps on the dense MuJoCo Hopper environment has been acquired as outlined in section 4.2
Code for applying Generative Adversarial Imitation Learning (GAIL) to a given SAC network agent has been implemented
An approximated policy network version of the pretrained SAC agent has been acquired using Generative Adversarial Imitation Learning (GAIL) as outlined in section 4.2
The pretrained agents have been refined using various methods for the same fixed number of steps (1M) on the dense MuJoCo Hopper environment
The pretrained SAC agent has been refined by further fine-tuning with SAC for 1M steps

The experimental results for Experiment V show that the proposed explanation method ("Ours") is not sensitive to changes in $\alpha$, with the fidelity score remaining comparable across the tested different values of $\alpha$
The experimental results for Experiment V show that refinement performance is lowest when $p=0$ or $p=1$
The experimental results for Experiment V show that refinement performance noticeably improves when $\lambda > 0$
